                    <gmd:citedResponsibleParty>

                            </gmd:organisationName>
                            <gmd:role>

                    <gmd:citedResponsibleParty>

                            </gmd:organisationName>
                            <gmd:role>
                                <gmd:CI_RoleCode
                                        codeList="https://schemas.isotc211.org/19115/-3/cit/1.0/codelists.xml#CI_RoleCode"

                        </gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>
                    </gmd:citedResponsibleParty>
                </gmd:CI_Citation>
            </gmd:citation>
            <gmd:abstract>
                <gco:CharacterString>The LakePulse Network performed a lake health assessment at the canadian scale. Launched in 2016 thanks to the funding of the NSERC (Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada) Strategic Partnership Program for Networks, LakePulse is an academic-government partnership that brings together 17 academic researchers from 13 Canadian universities, as well as eight provincial governments and two federal departments. Research interests were grouped under four research themes, with two to four projects within each theme. Approaches used in LakePulse include traditional, state-of-the-art and innovative methods in genomics, emerging contaminants, greenhouse gases, invasive pathogens, paleolimnology, spatial modelling, statistical analyses and remote sensing to answer the following main questions:

- How healthy are Canadian lakes?
- Is lake degradation widespread in Canada or worse in certain regions?
- Is lake health getting better, worse, or stable through time?
- How does land use and climate change affect lake health?</gco:CharacterString>
            </gmd:abstract>
            <gmd:credit gco:nilReason="missing"/>

                            <gmd:westBoundLongitude>

keywords_translation_method.fr: Keyword text translated using the Amazon translate service / texte traduit à l'aide du service Amazon translate

name: 10-25976-sd85-ov48
notes:
The LakePulse Network performed a lake health assessment at the canadian scale. Launched in 2016 thanks to the funding of the NSERC (Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada) Strategic Partnership Program for Networks, LakePulse is an academic-government partnership that brings together 17 academic researchers from 13 Canadian universities, as well as eight provincial governments and two federal departments. Research interests were grouped under four research themes, with two to four projects within each theme. Approaches used in LakePulse include traditional, state-of-the-art and innovative methods in genomics, emerging contaminants, greenhouse gases, invasive pathogens, paleolimnology, spatial modelling, statistical analyses and remote sensing to answer the following main questions:

- How healthy are Canadian lakes?
- Is lake degradation widespread in Canada or worse in certain regions?
- Is lake health getting better, worse, or stable through time?
- How does land use and climate change affect lake health?

notes_translated.en:
The LakePulse Network performed a lake health assessment at the canadian scale. Launched in 2016 thanks to the funding of the NSERC (Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada) Strategic Partnership Program for Networks, LakePulse is an academic-government partnership that brings together 17 academic researchers from 13 Canadian universities, as well as eight provincial governments and two federal departments. Research interests were grouped under four research themes, with two to four projects within each theme. Approaches used in LakePulse include traditional, state-of-the-art and innovative methods in genomics, emerging contaminants, greenhouse gases, invasive pathogens, paleolimnology, spatial modelling, statistical analyses and remote sensing to answer the following main questions:

- How healthy are Canadian lakes?
- Is lake degradation widespread in Canada or worse in certain regions?
- Is lake health getting better, worse, or stable through time?
- How does land use and climate change affect lake health?
notes_translated.fr:
Le réseau LakePulse a réalisé une évaluation de la santé des lacs à l'échelle canadienne. Lancé en 2016 grâce au financement du Programme de partenariat stratégique pour les réseaux du CRSNG (Conseil de recherches en sciences naturelles et en génie du Canada), LakePulse est un partenariat université-gouvernement qui réunit 17 chercheurs universitaires de 13 universités canadiennes, ainsi que huit gouvernements provinciaux et deux ministères fédéraux. Les intérêts de recherche ont été regroupés en quatre thèmes de recherche, avec deux à quatre projets dans chaque thème. Les approches utilisées dans LakePulse comprennent des méthodes traditionnelles, de pointe et innovantes en génomique, en contaminants émergents, en gaz à effet de serre, en agents pathogènes envahissants, en paléolimnologie, en modélisation spatiale, en analyses statistiques et en télédétection pour répondre aux principales questions suivantes :

- Quel est l'état de santé des lacs canadiens ?
- La dégradation des lacs est-elle généralisée au Canada ou est-elle pire dans certaines régions ?
- La santé des lacs s'améliore-t-elle, se dégrade-t-elle ou se stabilise-t-elle au fil du temps ?
- Comment l'utilisation des terres et le changement climatique affectent-ils la santé des lacs ?

description_translated.en: DataStream is an open access platform for sharing water and sediment quality data.
description_translated.fr: DataStream est une plateforme en libre accès pour partager des données sur la qualité de l'eau et des sédiments.
